title: Linux
summary: Linux is a free, open-source Unix-like operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds in 1991. It powers the majority of servers, supercomputers, Android devices, and embedded systems worldwide.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Bash (Unix Shell)
summary: Bash (Bourne Again Shell) is the default command-line shell on most Linux and macOS systems. It provides a powerful scripting language for automating tasks, managing files, and interacting with the operating system.
author: EduWiki Team

title: C Programming Language
summary: C is a general-purpose, procedural programming language created by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in the early 1970s. It remains one of the most influential and widely-used languages, powering operating systems, embedded systems, and system software.
author: EduWiki Team

title: C++ Programming Language
summary: C++ is a powerful, general-purpose programming language created by Bjarne Stroustrup as an extension of C. It adds object-oriented programming and is widely used for system software, game engines, and high-performance applications.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Citations Guide
summary: How to properly add and format citations and references in EduWiki articles.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: Love
summary: Love is one of the most fundamental concepts in philosophy and theology — examined through the Greek distinctions of agape, philia, and eros, and celebrated in Christian thought as the greatest of all virtues.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Nutrition
summary: Nutrition is the science of how living organisms obtain and use food for energy, growth, and health. Christian thought emphasizes care for the body as a temple of God.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ecology
summary: Ecology is the scientific study of interactions among living organisms and their environments. Christian stewardship ethics call believers to care for God's creation.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Psychology
summary: Psychology is the scientific study of mind and behavior. Christian psychology integrates faith and science, viewing the human person as made in the image of God with a soul, conscience, and free will.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Geology
summary: Geology is the science of the Earth — its materials, structures, processes, and history. Christians have engaged geology as a discipline that reveals the grandeur of God's creation.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Sociology
summary: Sociology is the study of human society, social institutions, and collective behavior. Christian sociology examines how covenant community, moral order, and the call to build Zion shape social life.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Agriculture
summary: Agriculture is the cultivation of crops and livestock for food, fiber, and fuel. Biblical and Christian traditions have always recognized farming as a sacred vocation tied to stewardship of the earth.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Formal Logic
summary: Formal logic is the study of valid inference using symbolic systems. From Aristotle's syllogisms to modern mathematical logic, it has been an indispensable tool of theology and natural philosophy.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Mathematical Proofs
summary: A mathematical proof is a logical argument that establishes a theorem beyond all doubt. The axiomatic method, developed by Euclid, reflects the Christian conviction that God's creation operates by rational, discoverable laws.
author: EduWiki Team

title: United States Government
summary: The government of the United States was shaped by classical Greek and Roman political philosophy, Christian natural law theory, and Enlightenment thought. Its founders drew deeply on Cicero, Aristotle, Polybius, and the English common law tradition.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Declaration of Independence
summary: The Declaration of Independence (1776) proclaimed the American colonies' separation from Britain and articulated a political philosophy rooted in Christian natural law, classical republicanism, and Enlightenment thought.
author: EduWiki Team

title: United States Constitution
summary: The United States Constitution (1787) is the supreme law of the land, establishing the framework of federal government. Its design reflects classical mixed-government theory, Christian natural law, and hard-won lessons from history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: American Revolution
summary: The American Revolution (1765–1783) was a political and military struggle that gave birth to the United States. The Founders drew heavily on classical Greek and Roman thought, Christian theology, and English constitutional precedent.
author: EduWiki Team

title: United States History
summary: United States history spans from the founding of the colonial settlements through the present day. The nation's classical and Christian foundations, its experiment in republican self-government, and its providential narrative are central themes.
author: EduWiki Team

title: American Civil War
summary: The American Civil War (1861–1865) was the defining crisis of American history, fought over slavery, states' rights, and the meaning of the Union. Christian moral arguments shaped both sides, and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address stands as one of the great theological documents of American life.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Brigham Young
summary: Brigham Young (1801–1877) was the second President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the leader of the pioneer exodus to the Utah Territory, and one of the most consequential figures in nineteenth-century American religious history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Socrates
summary: Socrates (c. 470–399 BC) was an Athenian philosopher widely regarded as the founder of Western philosophy. His Socratic method of questioning — preserved in Plato's dialogues — transformed how humanity thinks about ethics, knowledge, and the good life.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Plato
summary: Plato (c. 428–348 BC) was an Athenian philosopher, student of Socrates, and founder of the Academy. His Theory of Forms, political philosophy, and dialogues on the soul have shaped Western thought for two and a half millennia.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Aristotle
summary: Aristotle (384–322 BC) was a Greek philosopher and polymath — student of Plato, tutor of Alexander the Great, and founder of the Lyceum. He made foundational contributions to logic, metaphysics, ethics, biology, and political philosophy.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Marcus Aurelius
summary: Marcus Aurelius (AD 121–180) was Roman Emperor and Stoic philosopher whose private journal, the Meditations, is one of the most celebrated works of philosophical reflection ever written — a ruler's daily effort to live virtuously.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Stoicism
summary: Stoicism is a philosophical school founded in Athens c. 300 BC that holds virtue is the only true good and that happiness depends entirely on one's own character and judgments. It includes a rich metaphysics and a significant comparison between Greek and Roman Stoics.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Cicero
summary: Marcus Tullius Cicero (106–43 BC) was the greatest Roman orator, statesman, and the primary transmitter of Greek philosophy to the Latin world. His natural law theory became foundational for Christian political theology and Western jurisprudence.
author: EduWiki Team

title: William Shakespeare
summary: William Shakespeare (1564–1616) is the most celebrated writer in the English language. In 37 plays and 154 sonnets he explored the full range of human experience with a mastery of language and psychological insight that has never been surpassed.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ancient Hebrew
summary: Ancient Hebrew is the Semitic language of the Hebrew Bible and one of the oldest continuously attested literary languages in the world. It was the language of ancient Israel and Judah, and its root-and-pattern morphology gives it remarkable depth and coherence.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Dead Sea Scrolls
summary: The Dead Sea Scrolls are approximately 981 ancient Jewish manuscripts discovered near Qumran (1947–1956), dating from the third century BC to the first century AD. They are the oldest known manuscripts of the Hebrew Bible and the greatest archaeological find of the twentieth century.
author: EduWiki Team
